abstract.text: No overview available.
Return a new query with the last item removed.
Get the origins for all the items of this query.
Get the frames for all the items of this query.
Get a Query object containing the “inner” items
(i.e. from the middle of the array).
Set the minimum number to return.
The number of items returned will be even or odd
depending on if the original query is even or odd.
Act on the indexed item in a Query
without affecting the other items, or
the outer Query.
Traverse the items with a closure including the item ($0) and
any related item ($1) in the current query scope, by type and string id.
Useful for modifying item state based on other items.
Related item restricted to the first item found,
starting from the query base and working downward.
To debug the hierarchy used for the related item search precede
this call with
or
See also previousRelated() to search backwards from the current item(s).
Grab identifiable item of specified type (derivitive of T)
within the query scope (from base) and append it to
the results of the current query.
Will add if not already exists in items.
Does any item in the current query have a string tag
or if “allMatch” do all items have a string tag?
To test each item individually, nest this call in Query.lift().
Re-order query by specified type of ordering
or if using “ascending” or “descending” by
existing item ordinals.
Does any item in the current query have a tag
or if “allMatch” do all items have a string tag?
To test each item individually, nest this call in Query.lift().
Filter the queried items.
See also
Work on the queried items without breaking the outer chain.
This is where you do “aside” effects, and as such
should not be overused.
Get a query object containing item(s) at specified indices in range
acting on items within closure without affecting outer query.
Act on the queried items in closure providing the
count of those items as the second parameter.
Act on the prefix items in a Query up to
and including the provided index
without affecting the other items, or
the outer Query.
Lift each item in the current query into it’s own query.
Useful when it is necessary to treat each item separately
but still have the whole query/mutator interface.
Example, use lift to ensure that the reference is dynamically
queried relative to each item, for example, 4 items that
need to be positioned relative to
of their parents.
The lifted query includes the original base, reference
and other query state.
Does the current query have results
Example: if view.query.controls.hasItems { .. }
Get the first n items of the query
query.prefix(2)
Traverse the items with a closure including the item ($0) and any
related item ($1) in the current hierarchy, by type and optional identifier.
Useful for modifying item state based on other items.
Related item restricted to the first item found, starting
from the current item and working backwards (siblings and ancestors).
See also related() to start search for related items from query base.
Pass
to ignore parent guide
relationships in determining what is a “sibling”, or set
to false to
ignore parent guides for all previous queries, and then
override using
Specify
to include siblings or ancestor siblings that
are
the current item(s) in the hierarchy, but still “nearby”.
Grab orderable item of specified type (must be derivitive of T)
within the query scope (from base) and append it to
the results of the current query.
Will add if not already exists in items.
Get a Query object containing only the second queried item
Traverse the items with a closure including the item ($0) and
any related item ($1) in the current hierarchy, by type and ordinal.
Useful for modifying item state based on other items.
Related item restricted to the first item found, starting
from the current item and working backwards (siblings and ancestors).
See also related() to start search for related items from query base.
Pass
to ignore parent guide
relationships in determining what is a “sibling”, or set
to false to
ignore parent guides for all previous queries, and then
override using
Specify
to include siblings or ancestor siblings that
are
the current item(s) in the hierarchy, but still “nearby”.
Sort by ordinal
Save the geometry information of the current items to an
external variable.
If the query contains multiple items, the frame and position
values will be based on the union of the item frames.
Bounds, z position and anchor point information is recorded
for the first item only.
Re-order items using sorting callback
Get a Query object containing item(s) at specified indices
Get the sizes for all the items of this query.
Act on the suffix items in a Query from
the provided index without affecting the
other items, or the outer Query.
Group this query by predicate (based on query items), grouping
the query into separate queries to be handled independently via closure.
The predicate must return a Hashable value to use as the grouping key
(this can be a view, a string identifier, a number, etc).
Example: .group(by: { $1.containingView }) { $1.mutate.. }
The closure is passed the current group index and the last index.
Act on the third item in a Query
without affecting the other items, or
the outer Query.
query.third { $0.addEvent() }
Get the center positions for all the items of this query.
Act on the last item in a Query
without affecting the other items, or
the outer Query.
Lift each item in the current query into it’s own query
with an index for each item.
Useful when it is necessary to treat each item separately
but still have the whole query/mutator interface.
Example, use lift to ensure that the reference is dynamically
queried relative to each item, for example, 4 items that
need to be positioned relative to
of their parents.
Reduce this query to the remainder of items after dividing
by the provided divisor.
Modify the query
Return query only if is empty.
Re-order the current query items by their ordinals
as represented by an array of ordinals.
Act on the prefix items in a Query
without affecting the other items, or
the outer Query.
Temporarily store this query’s items weakly,
e.g. before entering an async closure.
Access an item at index
Randomize the order of the query
Access a random item
Capture the ordinal of a parent item of specified type
onto the child query items.
Grab tagged item of specified type (derivitive of T)
within the query scope (from base) and append it to
the results of the current query.
Will add if not already exists in items.
Perform a query within the scope of the current base item
and return the first item found.
See also “query(max)” to return specific number of items.
Get a Query object containing all but the last item.
Reverse the order of the query
Create new query with first item that satisfies predicate
Traverse the items with a closure including the item ($0) and
any related item ($1) in the current hierarchy, by type and string tag.
Useful for modifying item state based on other items.
Related item restricted to the first item found, starting
from the current item and working backwards (siblings and ancestors).
See also related() to start search for related items from query base.
Pass
to ignore parent guide
relationships in determining what is a “sibling”, or set
to false to
ignore parent guides for all previous queries, and then
override using
Specify
to include siblings or ancestor siblings that
are
the current item(s) in the hierarchy, but still “nearby”.
Perform a query within the scope of the current base item.
Act on the suffix items in a Query
without affecting the other items, or
the outer Query.
Get the last n items of the query
query.suffix(2)
Re-order some or all items by specified indices
with reordered items being located at the beginning
of the returned order.
Items that are not represented by the specified
indices will be appended to the end of the returned
items in indeterminate order, unless passing
“maintainTailOrder:true” which will ensure the
original item order is maintained for those items.
NOTE: maintaining tail order is less efficient.
NOTE: provided indices must exist in the current query.
Get a query object containing item(s) at specified indices in range
Act on the queried items in closure providing the
indices for those items as the second parameter.
Access the first item
Restore this query’s weakly stored items, assuming
they are still allocated, e.g. from within an async closure
Set an ordinal integer on the query items.
Passing autoincrement:true will increment each item
in the query by one from the original ordinal provided
or default to start from 0.
Get a query object containing item(s) at odd numbered indices.
Grab tagged item of specified type (derivitive of T)
within the query scope (from base) and append it to
the results of the current query.
Will add if not already exists in items.
Reduce this query to the remainder of items after dividing
by the provided divisor, and act on those items in a closure
without affecting the outer query.
Act on the items before the last item in a Query
without affecting the outer Query.
query.beforeLast { $0.addEvent() }
Grab identifiable item of specified type (derivitive of T)
within the query scope (from base) and append it to
the results of the current query.
Will add if not already exists in items.
Get a Query object containing an item at a specific index
Reduce this query to the quotient (aka “floor”) of items
after dividing by provided divisor, and act on those items
in a closure without affecting the outer query.
Does the current query have attached items.
Attached items are items that have a super item.
Get a Query object containing only the third queried item.
For items beyond the third item use
or
Get a Query object containing only the first queried item

optionally specifying the minimum
and/or maximum amount of items.
Add items to the current query if correct type/subtype.
Will only add if not exists.
Does not alter the Query type.
Get a Query object containing only the last queried item
Get the last items of a query from an index
Add query of items to the current query. Will succeed
if the added query items are of the same type/subtype.
Will add items onlyif not exists (union) preserving order.
Act on the first item in a Query
without affecting the other items, or
the outer Query.
query.first { $0.addEvent() }

starting from the query base and working downward.

Add item to the current query. Will succeed
if the added item is of the same type/subtype.
Will add item only if not exists (union).
Does not alter the Query type.
Perform a query within the scope of the current base item (with options).
Return query only if it has items.

act on those items within a closure without affecting outer query.

the results of the current query.

non-empty or specified minimum and/or maximum

Related item restricted to the first item found, starting
from the current item and working backwards (siblings and ancestors).
See also related() to start search for related items from query base.
For flexibility this method (by default) ignores parent
guide relationships in determining what is a previous related sibling.
Specify
to include siblings or ancestor siblings that
are
the current item(s) in the hierarchy, but still “nearby”.
Access the last item
Group this query by provided number of alternations, grouping
the query into separate queries to be handled independently via closure.
For example: given a query of items A,B,C,D with alternate(by:2)
two groups will be called with queries containing A,C and B,D, respectively.
The closure is passed the current (0-based) group index and the last index.
The group index can be used to determine which alternative is being used.
Get the bounds for all the items of this query.
Act on the items after the first item in a Query
without affecting the outer Query.
query.afterFirst { $0.addEvent() }
Act on the second item in a Query
without affecting the other items, or
the outer Query.
query.second { $0.addEvent() }
Get the first items of the query up to an index
Return a new query with the first item removed.
Traverse query in chunks (wrapped in a Query)
Is the current query empty?
